docs.lead_paragraph: A woman whose baby was stillborn as a result of prenatal testing cannot collect damages for her emotional distress, the state's highest court has ruled. In a brief, unsigned opinion, the New York Court of Appeals ruled Thursday that only in limited circumstances -principally where a parent witnesses the death or injury of a child - can one be compensated for such emotional injuries. In this case, the court noted, the mother did not learn that she had lost her baby until a month after the test, known as amniocentesis, was performed. The majority in the decision stated that people may not recover damages for any emotional harm they suffer as a result of injury to a third party - in this case the fetus - unless they are in the ''zone of danger'' themselves and experience their own trauma simultaneously.

headline.main: DAMAGES REFLECTED IN DEATH OF FETUS
